all_paragraphs: Previously, we looked at pre-infusion, pressure, and temperature with a few data sources to understand what provided the best extraction. Now, let’s look at grinding, distribution, and tamping.

The main metric used is Extraction Yield (EY) or Total Dissolved Solids (TDS). EY is calculated using TDS, output weight, and input weight. They are loosely correlated to taste, and being able to achieve a higher EY or TDS, so the aim is higher TDS or EY.

Socratic Coffee studied burr sharpness with respect to water retention, and the data when sorted doesn’t show much of a difference in terms of extraction. I would be curious if using multiple grind settings or beans would have provided a clearer picture.

They went on to look Extraction Yield, and the data both in sorted paired comparisons and just a line plot show sharper blades provide a higher extraction yield. Sharper blades most likely affect the grind distribution, but they did not go further into depth with those experiments.

Socratic Coffee also looked at grinder speed and how that affects the distribution of grounds. However, in the original graphs, they didn’t show all the speeds per roast, just a single graph. I split out their data, and you can see the middle section is affected the most by 500 RPM, so I zoomed in on that chunk of data. It’s tricky to show a distribution without seeing the effect on taste or TDS, but the key for shot consistency is to keep the RPM consistent.

Socratic Coffee has done a small study in headspace using a 20g basket and 22g basket. They used a box plot in their original presentation, but because of the low number of samples, I thought it would be better to plot out sorted samples. Box plots are great for summarizing data, but when the distributions aren’t Gaussian, it is hard to understand just the box plot. The best hint of a distribution not being Gaussian is when the median is offset from the mean. Ideally, they should be centered, and when it isn’t, an uneven distribution can indicate that the sampling size was too small.

So I estimated their raw data using their box plot, which gives min, max, median, 25% and 75% bounds. For ten samples, that information gives samples 1, 3, 7, and 10 immediately. The rest is an interpolation between points considering the median is the average of samples 5 and 6.
The result doesn’t show a clear difference, and further experiments weren’t done by Socratic Coffee or anyone else.

Socratic Coffee has looked at filter baskets a few times. First, they looked at generic vs VST & IMS, then generic vs IMS, then a larger sampling across four baskets: Generic, Pesado, Pullman, and VST. Pesado is in the IMS category. All of this data was originally in a box plot format, and I estimated raw samples from the box plot parameters.

Overall, it seems using any precision basket is better than generic. But what if we combine all of this data? How about a comparison? For VST, the results show they lead to a higher extraction. For the Pullman filter, it is less clear. For Pesado, there seems to be an increase, but it is unclear if it is better than VST.

For direct comparisons to VST, Pullman and Pesado slightly under-performed, but the statistical significance is unclear. A much larger comparison across roasts would definitely be interesting to have because even one roast isn’t guaranteed to tell the whole story. I wonder if some filters are better for certain grind distributions or roast levels but not others. Again, I am noting the lack of data, and it’s fantastic that there is any data like this available.

Over the years, multiple people have tried to improve coffee distribution using different techniques or tools. Between Compound Coffee and Socratic Coffee, there have been some interesting data points suggesting that most distributors do more harm than good.

The OCD tool has seemed like a must-have for a quality barista, but the data suggests otherwise. I even bought one, but I have moved to using only a bent paper clip instead. Socratic Coffee studied the OCD tool vs tapping the portafilter across three grinders. The grinder isn’t so important apparently, but shot time seems to vary widely.

If we take all of the samples, we actually have 30 samples for each, and now it’s straight forward to do a two-paired t-test that has meaningful results, and we get a p = 8.1384e-11 which means the difference between the two is statistically meaningful (p < 0.05 is statistically significant).
They then went to look at two more: the BT and OCD2 distribution tools. Both of which don’t perform well against the control sample.

Inside this data for OCD tools, they used three different grinders. So we could also do a grinder comparison. I looked at the data with and without sorting. Either way, the K30 looks like a better grinder in this experiment, but there was not an analysis on the grind distribution for this grind setting. It is not clear that each grinder was best dialed in; I would like to assume so, but I can’t be certain. This points to the difficulty of running espresso experiments and controlling all the variables.

Compound Coffee compared four methods of distribution, but they dumped their data into a table without graphs. I visualize them in two ways here. Both show that the answer is not clear, but the Stockfleth method seems to be a bit better. The OCD tool is not a clear winner, but it doesn’t do as poorly as in the Socratic Coffee experiments.
Compound Coffee did a second ground of distributors, but they all failed to do better than the good ole finger distribution.

It seems distribution tools aren’t so helpful, but it is not clear why. I would only suspect because most only affect the top half of the puck. I would have thought the Twister tool would have done better, but it did not.

Socratic Coffee looked at tamp pressure on extraction, and the results fly in the face of what many people claim is the right tamp pressure. This data only shows there is not a clear trend. The only thing that seems to have some thing interesting is that the extraction time for a 10 lbs tamp is slightly lower than others, but that doesn’t matter as long as the extraction is up. Otherwise, it appears a low tamp pressure slightly more than the weight of the tamper is necessary.

Socratic Coffee looked at a number of tampers, and the LM, Easy, and Pull (short for Pullman) all seem pretty similar. One could argue the Perg and Pull tampers are superior, but there isn’t enough evidence to make that claim.
Compound Coffee also looked at the LM, Pergtamp, and Levy. Their results seemed to have a stronger difference the Pergtamp and the Levy Tamp.

So, Compound Coffee went further to test a head-to-head between the two, and the Pergtamp was a clear winner. I even combined both dataset and ran a t-test. The sampling is only 25 samples, and it has a low p value of 0.0178, which shows for these samples, there a statistically significant difference.

Barista Hustle did a comparison between a barista (Jamie) stopping a shot based on weight versus letting the machine stop the shot at a specific volume. It was a test of machine vs human, and while a cluster of results show the machine won, there is still too much of a mix. The machine was definitely more consistent, but that doesn’t mean a skilled barista can’t pull amazing shots.

These were fun experiments to plot and analyze. I really enjoy looking across data sets especially given that these are small data sets, and it is unknown how coffee roast or bean plays into the results. However, we can derive some interesting notions suggested by this data:
I hope this collection of data could help inform or better yet inspire people to collect data. The next piece in this series will cover TDS measurement tools.
If you like, follow me on Twitter and YouTube where I post videos of espresso shots on different machines and espresso related stuff. You can also find me on LinkedIn.

I’m in love with my Wife, my Kids, Espresso, Data Science, tomatoes, cooking, engineering, talking, family, Paris, and Italy, not necessarily in that order.
